turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or any conversations in the editorial process may not be inquired into?

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: It seems to us that conversations --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's a considerably different kettle of fish than just talking about state of mind?

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: Well, that is -- it is a different area, Your Honor, it is and it seems to us that that also should be privileged, but that the policy basis for some of these are somewhat different and I tried to set forth but they aren't.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I get a hint from some of the things, at least between the lines of your argument Mr. Abrams, that perhaps some misreading of the opinions has taken place.
Is that a reasonable conjecture on my part?

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: Misreading of the opinions by --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Of the opinions of the Second Circuit, that some people may be misreading them.

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: I think that to the extent that -- yes.
Yes, I think that this is true.

That it is certainly misread if it is read as an end to libel law, and it is misread if it is read as a total, absolute privilege in every case which could conceivably be characterized as editorial process.
I don't think that's what it says, and I don't think that's what either Judge Kaufman or Judge Oakes have to say.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Abrams, before you sit down, when you started, you called my attention to page 53 (a) of the appendix.

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why did you do that?

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: I started to respond to a question that you had asked Mr. Lubell.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I'd be interested in your response.

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: Starting about halfway down on page 53 (a), there was an interview on the program with Bruce Potter, and that was, I think what Mr. Lubell was adverting to earlier and I described it briefly about how Mr. Potter said that in his presence Colonel Herbert had thrown a sandbag out and as well had made threatening gestures towards a prisoner of war.
Mr. Lubell's examples was that example, and what he said to you was that there were four people on the other side.
What I wanted to say in response to that was, first as a matter of fact, the four people were not on the helicopter and had nothing to say as such about what happened there.
But what they did say were good things about Colonel Herbert in terms of his desire to care for, to be compassionate towards prisoners of war and they were not on the program.

Although what was on the program was a statement of Mr. Wallace, saying in so many words, that there are people who they had interviewed, who CBS had interviewed, who took the position that Colonel Herbert was not capable of brutality.
The point that I was going to make was only this.

It seems to me that that is a very, very dangerous line for libel law to go down, either substantively or procedurally, if we're talking about procedure today, and allowing questions about that because the nature of those questions is nothing less than, why didn't you put the good material on?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, do you think that the question would be proper if it were asked this way, in the light of what these other four persons had to say, did you have any doubt about the credibility of Mr. Potter?

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: I certainly wouldn't have objected to a question asking whether he had any doubt about the credibility of what Mr. Potter had to say on the program.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Did he --

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: I'm sorry?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: (Inaudible) was Mr. Potter telling the truth?

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: In what he said on the program?
We --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, supposing this wasn't on the program but it was just one that was slightly different.
Well, you'd say that could be not inquired.

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: Then it seems to me that that is a further step away.
It seems to me that journalists ought to be responsible for what they put on.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why is one involved editorial process any more than the other?

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: Because it seems to me that when you put it -- I think they both involved conceptually the editorial process, but when the process is broadcast, it's out.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The process wasn't broadcast -- the product of the process?

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: When the segment at page 53 and 54 (a) is on the program, it seems to me, even though that is a result of a process, the journalist has to respond to the question as to whether he believed it or not.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It's permissible to ask why he put Potter's statement on, but it is not permissible to ask, why did you not put the other four statements on?

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: No, Your Honor, it is our position that it is permissible to ask, did you believe the statement of Mr. Potter which you broadcast and it is our position that the questions ought not to be allowed to the effect of, why did you put it on --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if there were a second statement by Mr. Potter, I just want to be sure I am --

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The second statement by Mr. Potter was somewhat similar, but was not actually put on the air.
It would not be permissible to say, did you believe that statement by Mr. Potter?

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, that is our position that that should not be permissible.
We think that the product broadcast ought to be what is at issue, and that that can be inquired into, but not the process by which other things did not get put on.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: floyd_abrams
turn.label: Mr. Floyd Abrams
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You have a few minutes left, Mr. Lubell.

turn.speaker: jonathan_w_lubell
turn.label: Mr. Jonathan W. Lubell
turn.text: Very briefly, in regard to reference to the Sullivan decision itself, the reference to the looking at the files, the issue that gets raised now by the Second Circuit decision is suppose an editor at the time that the work product was being worked up, the editorial process was going on, went to the files and looked at the files during that editorial process.
The question is, could we ask a question about what was done during the editorial process?
I think that question is a serious question in light of the decision of the Second Circuit which appears to say that we can't inquire as to what was done during that process.

In addition, in the Sullivan case itself, in reference to whether the media are the only groups of people that are protected under the Sullivan principles, I'm sure, needless to say, the Court is aware that individuals were as well, petitioners before this Court in Sullivan, the ministers themselves, and they were afforded the protection of the Sullivan principles as well as the New York Times.

So I think from Sullivan on, there has been at least an implied recognition that the Sullivan principles protect anyone who exercises his First Amendment rights, first in regard to public officials, and subsequently in the decisions of this Court in regard to public figures.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Lubell, let me ask you just one question.
At the end of Judge Oakes' opinion, his last sentence, it refers to that he concurs in the general answer of Chief Judge Kaufman to the certified question.
Was there a single question certified to the court?
That's on page 46(a) of the --

turn.speaker: jonathan_w_lubell
turn.label: Mr. Jonathan W. Lubell
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: There was a single -- where is it in the papers that have been filed?

turn.speaker: jonathan_w_lubell
turn.label: Mr. Jonathan W. Lubell
turn.text: I believe what he is referring to, Your Honor, is the certification memorandum opinion and order because as to whether you can specify and focus upon a specific certified question, I don't find it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The only certificate of the district judge would be under 1292(b) saying an interlocutory appeal is ordered, is that what he's talking about?

turn.speaker: jonathan_w_lubell
turn.label: Mr. Jonathan W. Lubell
turn.text: I believe so, and that is in the appendix to the petition, the second memorandum opinion and order of Judge Haight, beginning at 90(a) to the petition in which he certifies under 1292(b).

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, at the very beginning, the Court of Appeal's opinion says, appeal pursuant to 28 U.S.C. 1292(b)?

turn.speaker: jonathan_w_lubell
turn.label: Mr. Jonathan W. Lubell
turn.text: Yes, yes.
Yes, Your Honor.

It came up on a certified -- on a certification procedure and the certified question involved the same question that Judge Haight said was a question of first impression, which had to do with the state of mind, or whether there was a privilege for the editorial process of the press.

Further, in regard to the question that the Chief Justice posed to Mr. Abrams as to criminal cases where defendant does take the stand, or any civil case where defendant does take the stand, and the issue of state of mind is an issue, whether it would be because malice or intent required.
Obviously, the defendant must answer those questions unless a testimonial privilege against self-incrimination or one of the recognized testimonial privileges is asserted.
In this case, in fact, the defendant, in a pre-trial sense, took the stand.

He submitted himself to a deposition and questions were asked to him about his state of mind within concrete, factual contexts only because by the decisions of this Court, the subjective state of mind has become the critical Sullivan issue.

In regard to the -- again, back to the question of what questions appeared to be allowable, or would not appear to be allowable, I would note that the defendants have objected at the deposition stage, and have contended throughout the appeals here, that questions as to the defendants' view of the credibility and veracity of persons who appeared on the program, as well as persons who did not appear on the program, were not proper.
So, that it's not limited to somebody who did not appear on the program.

I see both my lights are on and in conclusion, we contend that by precluding a plaintiff from obtaining any direct evidence of state of mind in a Sullivan case, or obtaining any evidence of what happened in the editorial process, whichever way you interpret the two aspects of the Court of Appeals' decision completely unbalances the accommodation struck by this Court in Sullivan and its progeny.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
